bibl.title: Despatch from Ezekiel E. Smith to William F. Wharton, September 19, 1889
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consular General

div1.p: Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, September 19th, 1889
Mr. Ezekiel E. Smith To the Deartment of State.
Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, September 19th, 1889
Honorable William F. Wharton Acting Secretary of State, Wasington, D. C.

Sir: I have the honor respectfully to acknowledge the receipt of the Department Circular of August 3rd 1889, with reference to the financial condition of Liberia. It reached me on the 17th inst. and was tranmitted to the Secretary of State of Liberia on the morning of the 18th.
I beg to transmit, herein, a report on the Pilotage, Light Dues, Tonnage &c, as required by the laws of Liberia. The
The information contained in the reprint was asked, of the Secretary of State of Liberia, on the 24th of August, but not received until to days.
I have the honor to be, sir, your obedient servant,
Ezekiel E. Smith U.S. Consul General
1. Report on the Pilotage, Light Dues, Tonnage &c in Liberia.
